newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli Chamber chief blasts central bank.
newsitem.headline: Israeli Chamber chief blasts central bank.

text.p: The high interest rates imposed by the Bank of Israel are responsible for the slowing economy, Danny Gillerman, chairman of the Federation of Israeli Chambers of Commerce, said on Wednesday.
He described 1996 as a "lost" year for the economy because of its enormous growth potential at the end of 1995,
The Chamber said the slowdown in economic expansion in 1996 to an estimated 4.4 percent from 7.1 percent in 1995 equalled lost output of seven billion shekels.
But Gillerman said the actual cost was 10 billion shekels or more if the loss was measured against the economy's potential growth at the start of 1996.

Gillerman blamed the central bank's restrictive monetary policy for cutting into capital spending growth and increasing the government's budget deficit. "There is a complete correlation between rising interest rates and a rising deficit," he said.
Gillerman also blamed concerns about the future of Middle East peace for the economy's problems.

"There is no doubt part of the uncertainty comes from the political/security situation," he said. "Multinational companies are here for the long run....I have not head of a single company that was already here that left, but I see in the field that companies deciding whether to come to Israel are worried."

Gillerman called for a social-economic compact between employers, the government and labour unions to agree on a package of reform measures. Over the past week strikes called by the country's Histadrut trade union crippled some sectors as workers protested proposed economic austerity measures.
While Gillerman said he was encouraged by the budget cuts for 1997 passed by parliament on Wednesday, he added that without a commensurate cut in interest rates 1997 "will be a very bad year."
